issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify that the lectureName attribute is a String, but the solution repository changes the attribute type to a custom LectureName class. This is a cross-artifact attribute type mismatch that also changes the constructor parameter type: the solution's Lecture field is declared as LectureName and its constructor accepts LectureName, while the exercise expects a String lectureName (per UML and task text). This discrepancy will confuse students about the expected type and constructor signature and prevents straightforward implementation following the UML/specification.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the lectureName type consistent across artifacts. Either: (A) revert the solution to use a plain String for lectureName (change the field to String, change the constructor parameter to String, remove the LectureName helper class), which matches the UML and problem text; or (B) update the problem statement and template to explicitly use and document the LectureName type (showing its purpose and required methods) so all artifacts consistently expect LectureName. Option A is recommended to minimize changes and match the original UML.

issues.description: The solution's getter and setter for lectureName have signatures that conflict with the declared field type in the solution. In solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Lecture.java the field is declared as LectureName, but getLectureName() is declared to return String and setLectureName(String) accepts a String. These mismatched types cause compile errors and contradict the intended getter/setter types implied by the problem (which expects String).
issues.suggested_fix: Align getter and setter signatures with the chosen field type. If lectureName remains a String (recommended): change the field type to String, ensure getLectureName() returns String, and setLectureName(String) stores the String. If keeping LectureName, then change getLectureName() to return LectureName and setLectureName(...) to accept a LectureName parameter, and update the problem statement/template to reflect this API. Ensure return/parameter types are consistent to avoid compile errors.

issues.description: The problem statement requires an attribute lectureName of type String (explicitly listed among the attributes to add). The solution repository, however, replaces this straightforward String with a new wrapper class LectureName and declares the Lecture.lectureName field as type LectureName. This introduces a new identifier (the LectureName class) and a type-level abstraction that is not present or mentioned in the problem statement or the template. Additionally, the solution's getter/setter signatures for lectureName use String while the field is declared as LectureName, creating an internal inconsistency in the solution. Together these differences (1) break the simple one-to-one mapping the problem expects between the conceptual attribute lectureName and an actual String field, (2) add an unexpected abstraction that students must understand or reconcile, and (3) may cause confusion or compile errors when students compare the problem, template, and solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the representation of the lectureName concept consistent across artifacts. Either (A) revert the solution to use a plain String field for lectureName (private String lectureName) and adjust the getters/setters and constructor accordingly, removing the LectureName class; or (B) update the problem statement and template to explicitly introduce and document the LectureName wrapper type (and adjust signatures in the template) so students expect that abstraction. Also fix the solution's getter/setter signatures so their declared parameter/return types match the actual field type.
